transcripts.text: Steve, I got it.  I got your point.  The argument would be that it's a false choice you're making.  He either takes place a rosy scenario or he sets his hair on fire.  There is something in the middle, which is just being honest with the American people.

Take a listen to this exchange between Fox News host Chris Wallace and Trump advisor Steve Cortez as Cortez tries to justify the panic that Donald Trump is trying to cause around Joe Biden.  while saying that he didn't want to panic the American people around COVID-19.

Steve, your explanation is somewhat different from the president because you're saying, well, the president didn't really know it was the fog of war.  But when he has described it, he said he didn't want to panic the country.  He didn't want to jump up and down and panic the country.  And one of the reasons that there's a question about that is because of the fact that the president plays the panic card all the time, especially when he's talking about Joe Biden.  Take a look.
If Biden wins, the mob wins.
If Biden wins, the rioters, anarchists, arsonists and flag burners win.  Peaceful protest.  Peaceful protest.  Is that a president who is trying to keep the country calm?

There's a key difference here.  When the president is talking about legitimate fear of what can happen in America if Joe Biden were to win, and if disrespect for the police were to continue to become the norm in this country, he is trying to exhort the American people to action, to say, we can stop this.  We can back the police.  We can restore order.  We can insist on the rule of law.
